markdownRemark.html:
Deepfake is an AI technology that digitally alters a person’s face so that they appear to be someone else. It is often used with bad intentions. We turned the tables and found a use for good. Blocktag uses deepfake to digitally alter an original tag so that you can anticipate how counterfeit tags look like.

Deep Learning For Print Physics

Blocktag’s deepfake technology learns the physics of printing to predict how photocopied tags printed on different printer models will look like. Below is an image rendering of deepfake reprints and photocopies.

Deep Learning For Print Material Detection

Moreover, print physics differs on different paper types. Deepfake tags can be created more accurately if you know what material or paper is the tag printed on. The material or paper type is also useful to check print quality for users that print tags on home printers. Blocktag can infer paper type by seeing a tag’s surface texture with AI computer vision. An AI model is trained on images of tags printed on known paper types (Normal, cardboard, glossy, photo quality etc.)

Deep Learning For Camera Resolution Correction

Blocktag can also use AI to customize how deepfake tags look like on different phone cameras. Because cameras with different resolutions perceive the printed original tag at different sharpness. Sharper pixels can be misinterpreted as extra chaotic print artifacts from a photocopied tag. Blocktag AI corrects the camera focus to ensure a fair comparison between original and deepfake tags.

3D Space Visualisation For Deepfake Authentication

Blocktag uses deepfakes to improve authentication accuracy. As we collect more training data from user authentications to train our deep learning model, there are more deepfake datapoints to tighten the authentication criteria. You can visualize this in the graph below. The 3 axes represents the target tag’s red,green and blue colored pattern's similarity with the original fingerprint. The boxed space bounded by the 3 colored planes represent successful authentication. Each colored datapoint represents a tag instance.

Black: Deepfake tag.
White: Target tag to be authenticated.
Gray: Past authentication sessions of the target tag.
Gold: Original tag's fingerprints. The ground truth gold standard.

Deepfake empowers a brand’s users as anti-counterfeiting's first line of defense. Before counterfeiters try to fake it till they make it.

ChunMing Chin
Cofounder, Director of Engineering
Blocktag Inc
